addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

Vij A
p
1592
M
r
Bodeleie to my L./.
Barnevelt
allowinge of his motion for forces to be sent into
France.
12 Ships to be sent on
e Cost of
Britaigne.
Merchant
Adventurers
.

page.lettertext:
fol.209r
May it please yo
r
good L. Wheras an extraor-
dinarie contribution, of ninetie thousand pounde
sterling, hath bin required of
e Provinces, it fal-
leth out among
e Deputies, in c
o
ferring their
commissions, that onely
Zeland
is unwilling, not
resolving to contribut, but after
e rate of five-
tie thousand pou nde ster
l
. Howbeit there is
already order taken,
at
Count Maurice
with
certaine of
e states assemblie, and of
e
Councell,
shall p
nt
ly into Zeland, to persuade them to con-
curre w
t
e rest of
e Provinces. Sins the
writing of my last
e 1 of this moneth, I have
bin in communication w
t
divers of the state,
and w
t
Barnevelt in speciall, who I thought
Barnevelt
allowance of
his moti
o
for France.
above
e rest, for displeasing the Count, would
not favo
r
that motion, for sending succo
rs
into
France. But I finde him as forward, as I could
desire. All his doubt is of
e meanes, to bring it
well to passe, w
t
every Provinces contentac
o
n.
But I told him againe, and he seemed to assent,
that if
e motion be embraced, by those
at are
deputed to
e government of
e state, there is no
hardnes in winning
e peoples good liking.
This talke I had w
t
him by way of discourse,
and not as charged to persuade it: albeit I
could perceave,
at
M
r
Buzenval
had bin with
Buzenvals backwardnes.
him, and told him my designe: as I feare in
conversation w
t
e people of this contrey, he doth
many more badde offices, in seconding suche humo
rs
,
as are not well affected to her
Ma
ties
proceedinges.
The states have bin in conference about
e maters of
Britaine,
and are half determined to
Britaigne.
send unto her Ma
tie
to
e F
r
Kinge, and to
e towne
of
Rochel,
at by common advise some plotte may
be devised, for freeing
at coast in regard of their
trafficke, and for offending
e Enemie, w
ch
is setled
fol.209v
there already: but as yet they have not taken any
final resolution, differring till Count Maurice
be returned out of Zeland, who departeth to mo-
rowe, and comes againe, as we suppose, w
t
in these
8 daies at
e furthest. In
e meane season it is
agreed by provision, that for
e assurance of their
marchants, there shall be 12 shippes of warre sent
thither, out of hande. In
e maters de-
Marchant
Adventurers.
pending between
e states and
e marchants Adven-
turers, I have travelled w
at
I can, to bring them to
accord: but heere they stand stiffely to
e equitie of
their Placcartes, and have framed an answear to
her Ma
ties
letters, w
ch
I have consigned to
e Gover-
no
r
of
e Company, from whome her Hig
nes
l
re
s were
sent unto me hither. Sins their answear was
made, I have moved them earnestly, to growe to
some accorde by c
o
munications of committies, to be
chosen on bothe sides, and while they are in c
o
fe-
rence, to lette their trafficke have his course, ta-
king notes of suche tares, as shall be made in our
clothes, for w
ch
they shall have allowance, accord
i
g
to
at order, wheron they shall resolve. Howe
neere they will be brought, to condescend to this
demande, I can not yet advertise. For they seeme
not wholy to dislike it, and yet they cast many
doubtes, to
put
it of for this p
nt
. I should
but trouble yo
r
L. to discourse unto yo
w
all,
at
hath passed in o
r
conference. So muche as is re-
quisit, I have written to
e companies at
Lond
o
,
and
Middelbourgh.
I send yo
r
L. heer-
w
t
a translated copie of
e answear, w
ch
was made
unto
e
Empero
rs
Ambassado
r
,
w
ch
I thinke notw
t
-
standing will be sent to her Ma
tie
by
e states th
e
selves.
And so I take my humble leave. Hage A
p
7
1592. Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
